qas.question: What is the Arabic term for the surface-level aspects of a text?
What Arabic term applies to interpretations aimed at the deeper, esoteric meanings of a text?
Who is the only one who ever knows the full meaning of Quranic verses in the esoteric view?
Which two groups are examples of Muslims who advocate a very literal reading of the Quran?
What is the Jewish term for the surface-level aspects of a text?
What is the Arabic term for the surface-level aspects of a song?
What Arabic term applies to misinterpretations aimed at the deeper, esoteric meanings of a text?
Who is the only one who ever knows the partial meaning of Quranic verses in the esoteric view?
Which two groups are examples of Muslims who advocate a very unliteral reading of the Quran?

context: Commentaries dealing with the <a0_0><b4_0><b5_0>zahir<b5_0/><b4_0/><a0_0/> (outward aspects) of the text are called tafsir, and hermeneutic and esoteric commentaries dealing with the batin are called <a1_0><b6_0>ta'wil<b6_0/><a1_0/> ("interpretation" or "explanation"), which involves taking the text back to its beginning. Commentators with an esoteric slant believe that the ultimate meaning of the Quran is known only to <a2_0><b7_0>God<b7_0/><a2_0/>. In contrast, Quranic literalism, followed by <a3_0><b8_0>Salafis and Zahiris<b8_0/><a3_0/>, is the belief that the Quran should only be taken at its apparent meaning.[citation needed]
